byline.contributor: Niki Kitsantonis reported from Athens, and James Kanter from Brussels. Alison Smale contributed reporting from Berlin, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.
byline.original: By NIKI KITSANTONIS and JAMES KANTER

abstract: Greece requests three-year loan from eurozone’s bailout fund, but does not publicly specify an amount or a plan for strengthening the government's finances; Eurozone leaders have rebuked Greek Prime Min Alexis Tspiras for not providing a new and specific proposal to secure additional bailout money, and European leaders are approaching deadline for negotiations, after which Greece may face bankrupt future outside eurozone.
lead_paragraph: Under a tight deadline from Europe, Greece applied for a bailout loan, and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras took his case to the European Parliament.

headline.main: Greece Requests a 3-Year Loan but Is Vague on Its Financial Plans
headline.print_headline: Athens Requests a 3-Year Loan but Is Vague on Its Financial Plans

snippet: Under a tight deadline from Europe, Greece applied for a bailout loan, and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras took his case to the European Parliament.
